awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Renewable Energy Generation and Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Along with the growing need for renewable energy generation and storage technologies is the need for a well-trained workforce with the skills to develop, deploy, and manage future energy technologies. Taking advantage of Binghamton University’s extensive infrastructure and faculty strength in renewable energy research, this Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site addresses scientific and training needs in materials research relating to the energy sector. The site brings together undergraduates from across the country, with a majority of participants coming from groups that are underrepresented in science and engineering, and from community colleges or small universities with limited research infrastructure. The participants engage in 10 weeks of intensive research on energy-related materials, while weekly workshops foster professional development and career planning. Building on past successes, this third phase of the REU site adds new opportunities for participants to learn about industry careers through interactions with companies at the Southern Tier Clean Energy Incubator. 
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: This REU site’s activities center on fostering development of the undergraduate participants into highly qualified scientists and engineers who are prepared to work in the energy sector. Towards this end, a supportive environment is created for the participants to solve fundamental materials research problems with connections to renewable energy generation and storage, using both experimental and computational strategies. Mentored by faculty spanning five science and engineering departments, and research teams in the NorthEast Center for Chemical Energy Storage, the Center for Autonomous Solar Power, and the Advanced Catalysis for Energy Sustainability Center, students tackle challenges in developing materials for solar energy conversion, mechanical energy harvesting, heat transfer, battery storage, and clean fuel generation. In partnership with the Southern Tier Clean Energy Incubator, participants learn about industry careers and the steps involved in translating laboratory innovations into commercial products. Students gain further preparation for science and engineering careers through workshops on communication, collaboration, and career pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this REU site were to (1) stimulate student interest in interdisciplinary research, (2) prepare students for careers in science and engineering, with a focus on energy generation and storage, and (3) expand the diversity of students involved in research. To achieve these objectives, participants engaged in energy-focused research under the guidance of faculty, industry partners, and graduate students; participants took part in a series of professional development activities; and participants were recruited from colleges and universities with limited research infrastructure and from groups that are underrepresented in STEM.

Working across disciplines spanning physics, chemistry, materials science, mechanical engineering, and electrical engineering, students gained skills in research methods, team collaboration, and communication, all of which helped prepare them for careers in STEM fields, including the energy sector. Working alongside graduate students, they were able to experience several weeks in the life of those graduate students while pursuing their own unique research questions.  Concurrently, graduate students working with the participants gained valuable experience in mentoring. In addition, five NSF-funded students were mentored by local industry experts, thus expanding their perspectives on potential careers in the energy sector.

The REU students participated in a series of workshops to further develop their career goals and preparedness. Topics included energy research, research ethics, research communication, graduate school, career paths, teamwork, and preparing a professional portfolio. A field trip to iM3NY, New York State's first battery gigafactory, introduced participants to battery manufacturing equipment, processes, and careers. The students also honed their communication skills during research discussions, mid-summer research presentations, and a university-wide poster session. Informal group activities were held to support further peer-learning and networking. 

This program helped to grow the STEM pipeline and increase the involvement of individuals from underrepresented populations in STEM careers. A total of 29 students participated in the program in its four-year span, including 23 with NSF stipend support, and 6 with support from the campus. The pool of participants included representation across chemistry, physics, and engineering. The diverse pool of NSF-supported students included 52% that were women, 57% that were ethnic minority students, 61% from small 4-year colleges and community colleges, and 61% that were early-stage undergraduates, having just completed their freshman or sophomore year. In addition to interacting with a diverse group of students, graduate students, and mentors within this REU site, participants also networked with students and faculty from other on-campus summer research programs.

Unlike many internship experiences that were cancelled during the COVID-19 pandemic, the Energy REU Site was able to adapt, following a fully remote model (2020), predominantly with computational research projects, and then a hybrid model (2021), combining remote contact and in-person learning. As a result, these experiences were made available to participants during a period when few undergraduate research opportunities existed.

Participants left their summer experience with a broader and more grounded view of graduate school and STEM careers. At the program outset, 59% of NSF-supported participants planned to apply to graduate school; by the end of the summer, 82% planned to apply. Both faculty mentors and REU students felt that the students had improved their lab and/or computational skills, their ability to conduct research, and their understanding of renewable energy topics. The research performed by the participants helped to advance multiple areas of energy science and technology, including energy generation in solar cells, hydrogen fuel generation, energy storage in fuel cells and batteries, mechanical energy harvesting, and smart grids.
